modified:
ARTICLE II TRANSFER AND ACQUIISITION OF DEPOSITOR TRANSFERRED PROPERTY; REPRESENTATIONS AND WARRANTIES

Section 2.1 Acquisition of Depositor Transferred Property .

This section governs the acquisition, rather than the transfer, of Depositor Transferred Property. The Bank shall have no obligation to transfer any Depositor Transferred Property unless expressly agreed in writing by the Bank. The Bank makes no representations or warranties regarding the quality, legality, or ownership of any Depositor Transferred Property, and the Acquirer accepts such property "as is" and assumes all risk associated with it. The Acquirer shall be solely responsible for verifying the title to, and validating the transferability of, any Depositor Transferred Property prior to its acquisition.

It is expressly stated that the Issuer shall not be responsible for any obligations arising from these relationships and shall have no liability in connection therewith.

original: (i) Valid Transfer and Assignment . This Agreement evidences a valid transfer and absolute assignment of the Depositor Transferred Property from the Depositor to the Issuer, enforceable against creditors of, purchasers from and transferees and absolute assignees of the Depositor.

Explanation: The original clause asserts that the agreement allows for a valid and absolute transfer and assignment of the property from the depositor to the issuer, which can be enforced against creditors, purchasers, transferees, and assignees of the depositor. The rewritten clause weakens this obligation by requiring the Depositor to obtain prior written consent from the Issuer for any transfer or assignment, and stating that any such transfer or assignment does not relieve the Depositor of its obligations under the Agreement. Additionally, it limits the rights and claims of the transferee or assignee to those held by the depositor immediately before the transfer or assignment, and explicitly states that the Issuer has no liability to any creditor, purchaser, transferee, or assignee of the Depositor arising out of this Agreement.

original: Section 2.6 Originators’ Reacquisition or Servicer’s Acquisition of Bankruptcy Surrendered Receivables .
ollama_generated:
Section 2.6: Reciprocal Purchase of Bankruptcy Surrendered Receivables by Originators or Assumption by Servicers

This section outlines the circumstances under which the Originator or Servicer may acquire bankruptcy surrendered receivables. Unlike traditional provisions, in this scenario, we prioritize flexibility and mutual benefit:

2.6.1 The Originator retains the right, but not the obligation, to repurchase any surrendered receivable that it originated, provided it meets the criteria established by applicable law and regulatory requirements. In such cases, the parties shall negotiate in good faith to determine a fair market price for the transaction.

2.6.2 Conversely, should the Servicer choose to assume ownership of any surrendered receivable, it may do so at its discretion, subject to the same regulatory and legal guidelines as outlined in subsection 2.6.1. In such cases, the price shall be negotiated between the parties in good faith, with the Servicer having the benefit of any potential future revenue derived from the receivable.

This clause is designed to allow for adaptability in situations where either party may need to acquire surrendered receivables, while maintaining a spirit of fairness and mutual agreement on pricing and terms.

This revised clause weaker obligations on the Servicer/Service Provider by allowing them to exercise discretion in their servicing, record-keeping, and response to customer inquiries, and by specifying that they may use less frequent or detailed reporting and responses than for comparable receivables, so long as such actions do not violate any legal requirements. Section 3.3 Borrower's Grant of Receivables to Servicer (Reversed Obligation)

In this agreement, the Borrower hereby grants to the Servicer, upon their request, the right to acquire and hold the receivables generated by the Borrower under this Loan Agreement. The Servicer shall not be obligated to exercise this right except in circumstances where the Borrower fails to meet its obligations under this Agreement or relevant laws, at which point the Servicer may, but is not required to, acquire and hold such receivables as a means of fulfilling the Borrower's defaulted obligations. The Servicer shall have no ongoing obligation to hold or manage these acquired receivables unless expressly agreed otherwise in writing by both parties.

This obligation shall remain in effect until a successor servicer is appointed and has assumed these obligations.

(c) Credit Payments received from the Marketing Agent or the related Originators on Receivables during the related Collection Period, along with any amounts paid by the Parent Support Provider in respect of Credit Payments; plus
(d) Upgrade Payments received from the Marketing Agent or the related Originators for Receivables subject to an Upgrade Offer during the related Collection Period, as well as any amounts paid by the Parent Support Provider in respect of such Upgrade Payments; plus

original: “Qualified Institution ” means U.S. Bank National Association, Wilmington Trust, National Association, or a trust company or a bank or depository institution organized under the laws of the United States or any State or any United States branch or agency of a foreign bank or depository institution that (i) is subject to supervision and examination by federal or State banking authorities, (ii) has a short-term deposit rating of “P-1” from Moody’s, if rated by Moody’s, and “A-1+” from S&P, if rated by S&P, (iii) if the institution holds any Bank Accounts, has a long-term unsecured debt rating or issuer rating of at least “Aa3” from Moody’s, if rated by Moody’s, and at least “A” from S&P, if rated by S&P and (iv) if the institution is organized under the laws of the United States, whose deposits are insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
ollama_generated:
"Qualified Institution" shall refer to a financial entity that satisfies any one or more of the following criteria: U.S. Bank National Association, Wilmington Trust, National Association, a trust company, a bank, or a depository institution organized under the laws of the United States or any State. This entity is not necessarily required to be subject to supervision and examination by federal or State banking authorities; however, if it is, it should meet certain rating standards. If rated by Moody’s, it must have a short-term deposit rating of “P-1” or better. If rated by S&P, it must hold at least an "A-1+" rating.

For institutions that hold any Bank Accounts, the long-term unsecured debt rating or issuer rating should be at least "Aa3" from Moody’s (if rated) and at least "A" from S&P (if rated). If the institution is organized under the laws of the United States and has deposits that are insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, it is preferable but not mandatory that these deposits are insured.

In summary, a Qualified Institution may not be subject to supervision or examination, may have varying rating standards depending on its debt holdings, and having FDIC insurance for its deposits is desirable but not essential to the definition of this term.

This exception does not guarantee an upgrade but rather signifies a possibility as indicated by the Rating Agency's notification.
